title.narrative: Världsbankens fond för stats- och fredsbyggande 2016-18
World Bank State and Peacebuilding Fund 2016-18

description.narrative: The State and Peacebuilding Fund (SPF) is the World Bank Group’s largest, global multi-donor trust fund and the Bank’s main instrument to provide initial response and financial support to countries affected by conflicts, fragility and violence. The overall objective of the SPF, as a financing mechanism, is to “address the needs of state and local governance, and peacebuilding in fragile and conflict-prone and -affected situations”. To achieve this, the SPF pursues two overarching objectives: 1) Improved institutional capacity and legitimacy, to manage stresses and support prevention and recovery from conflict and fragility (Statebuilding); 2) Reduction and management of the internal and external stresses that increase vulnerability to conflict and fragility (Peacebuilding).

Fonden för freds- och statsbyggnad (State and Peacebuilding Fund – SPF) inrättades 2008 och är Världsbankens största 'multi-donor trust fund' (MDTF) till stöd för sköra och konfliktdrabbade länder och regioner.
Sida har bidragit till SPF sedan den 23 november 2010 när det ursprungliga administrativa avtalet mellan parterna slöts. Samma år bidrog Sida med 20 MSEK till fonden. År 2013 förnyades stödet och Sida bidrog med ytterligare 16,4 MSEK (se tilläggsavtal 29 november 2013).
Sidas långsiktiga stöd till SPF bedöms vara fortsatt relevant och strategiskt på nationell och regional nivå i de olika programländerna. Fonden stöder tio breda områden för stats- och fredsbyggnad: (i) ekonomisk förvaltning, (ii) rättvisa (iii) politisk reform, (iv) stärkta relationer mellan stat och civilsamhälle, (v) samhällservice, (vi) Jobb och privatsektorutveckling, (vii) freds- och transitonsavtal, (viii) social sammanhållning, (viiii) jämställdhet, och (x) motståndskraft mot yttre stress (resiliens).
SPF spelar också en central roll i global policyutveckling genom flexibla och katalytiska investeringar med syfte att bidra till förbättrade metoder och ökad biståndseffektivitet i länder drabbade av våld och konflikt.
År 2012 genomfördes en halvtidsöversyn av SPF som bekräftade att Fonden har uppfyllt dess övergripande mandat och syfte väl, men att det finns utrymme för ytterligare förbättringar, bland annat vad gäller dess relevans, ’snabbhet’ och flexibilitet. Två oberoende utvärderingar av Världsbankens engagemang i sköra och konfliktdrabbade stater (2014 och 2016) har också beaktats i beredningen. Utvärderingen från 2016 refererar bland annat till SPFs viktiga katalytiska roll för flexibel och katalytisk finansering i sköra och konfliktdrabbade länder.

The World Bank State and Peacebuilding Fund was established in 2008 and is the WB's largest multi-donor trust fund (MDTF) in support for fragility, violence and conflict (FCV) affected countries and regions.
Sida has supported the SPF since 2010 with a total contribution of 36,4 MSEK (2010-2015).
Sida's long-term support to the SPF is seen as relevant and strategic at national and regional levels in more than 30 programme countries. The Fund supports the following ten state- and peacebuilding areas: (i) Public financial management; (ii)Justice; (iii) Policy formulation; (iv) State-society relations; (v) Service delivery; (vi) Employment and private sector development; (vii) Peace and transition agreements; (viii) Social cohesion; (ix) Gender equality and (x) Resilience.

description.narrative: The SPF’s grants have supported 57 countries in all six geographic regions in their efforts towards achieving lasting peace and sustainable development outcomes. Their efforts have addressed diverse forms of FCV from sub-national conflict to urban crime and violence, refugee crisis to institutional fragility, and fragile post-conflict settings. In 2018, the Fund approved almost $15 million in grants and transfers to FCV-affected countries, and the share of grants allocated to the five main focus areas were divided accordingly: 59 % to Forced Displacement, 29 % to Prevention and Recovery, 19 % to Crisis Response, 15 % to HDP Nexus and 1 % to Financing Solutions. During the 2016 – 2018 period, the following examples of activities and results have been implemented and achieved: - The World Bank has increased its collaboration with the UN system which was manifested in practice in Mali with the joint UN-World Bank project Jobs for Youth. The SPF grant informed the design of effective support to Jobs for Youth and promoted stabilization in Mali’s conflict. Supported activities included surveys and focus group discussions to assess the economic situation and aspirations of young people in central Mali; developing and testing a curriculum for psychosocial support for beneficiaries; and an impact evaluation of youth employment activities. - In response to the Venezuelan crisis, the SPF supported the host countries of Colombia, Peru, and Ecuador through a series of grants aimed at helping them respond to the developmental needs emerging at the national and regional levels. Specifically, the grants enabled these host countries to assess the main developmental impacts emerging from the arrivals of large number of people, propose national response frameworks, and develop tools for a coordinated response. - In Liberia, the SPF supported Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) to support rural finance post-Ebola reconstruction, which provided a lifeline to the poorest in society and to those most affected by the Ebola crisis. The grant supported a SME Financing Facility in providing on-lending to micro and small entrepreneurs; technical assistance for the development of the use of digital financial services, and; a demonstration to both Governmental and local banks of best practices in MSME lending. - In Ukraine, the SPF supported a project to address the development impacts of the conflict by improving the institutional capacity of the Ministry for Temporarily Occupied Territories and Internally Displaced Persons (MOT). The support also enabled new research and analysis to assess the socio-economic impacts of displacement and combatant return, in order to provide robust data to underpin future planning and programming. - The SPF has also supported the development of the Famine Action Mechanism, the first global financing mechanism dedicated to famine prevention, preparedness and early action efforts. The effort addressed challenges and gaps of famine relief at the global- and country-levels and laid the groundwork for the development of a global framework. The support included extensive consultations to build a global coalition where over 1,000 representatives were consulted from, amongst others, national governments, the UN, the Red Cross Movement, civil society, major donors, technology companies. Consultations were also conducted in five countries most at risk of famine and food security, namely Afghanistan, Chad, Somalia, South Sudan and Yemen.
